title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additionally, there is a provision for additional emergency CDBG funding. $1,000,000,000 is authorized to assist States, cities, and counties with community development block grants for foreclosure impact and rental assistance. $1,000,000,000 is authorized for housing foreclosure impact, community development, and rental assistance. Funds cannot be used for homeowner foreclosure prevention, only for rental assistance. The curr_chunk discusses the allocation of funds for foreclosure prevention purposes, including refinancing assistance and loans, to certified housing counseling services. These services are approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25% for funds allocated under it. At least 50% of the funds must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals. Plans and reports are also required. (a) Comprehensive Plan.--Funds under this Act require a detailed plan for approval by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
(b) Report on Use of Funds.--Recipients must submit quarterly reports accounting for fund usage. Each State, metropolitan city, or urban county receiving funds under this Act must submit quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development detailing the use of the funds. SEC. 6. WAIVERS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, except for certain requirements like fair housing and labor standards, upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive requirements for the use of funds upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county, if a compelling need is demonstrated. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive the public service requirement cap upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant waivers for the public service requirement cap if a compelling need is shown. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register and reviewed every two years for reauthorization. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant waivers for the public service requirement cap if a compelling need is shown, to be reconsidered and reauthorized every 2 years. The Secretary must notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waiver granted or denied at least 5 days before the decision. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of section 111 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. GAO will conduct audits on the use of funds appropriated under this Act. The Act applies section 111 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 to funds used under it. The Comptroller General will audit fund expenditures and report to specific committees. SEC. 9. REPORTS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations regarding the use of funds, number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, names of certified housing counseling services, and any other relevant information. The Secretary must report quarterly to Congress on the use of funds, households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, certified housing counseling services, and steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse of funds.
